description.narrative: To integrate conflict sensitivity into Citizens# Charter Afghanistan Project (CCAP), thus strengthening processes, plans and ultimately positive development outcomes. 1. What are the key drivers of conflict at the district and village levels? 2. To what degree doCDPs actively address, or unintentionally exacerbate, these underlying drivers of conflict within the specific area covered by the plans? 3. To what degree are the processes employed to develop and implement CDPs themselves conflict sensitive? 4. How can CDPs be adapted to maximise potential positive impacts on underlying drivers of conflict? Geographic focus areas: # Daikundi: 5 CDCs in Nili # Bamyan: 5 CDCs in 1 district # Herat: 5 CDCs in urban and 5 CDCs in rural (Zanda Jan) Data gathering and analysis processes: 1. Refine scope of analysis: Agreeing on core objectives of analysis, identifying focus areas, developing and refining research questions, developing criteria for selected social organisers/ geographic focus areas. 2. Literature review: Identify key conflict drivers, actors and how CCAP intersects with these. Use this to refine research questions further. 3. Develop detailed research methodology: Identify key groups to engage, develop interview questions, identify PRA tools for community engagement (building from existing tools used in CCAP), lay out ethnical guidelines and communications plan, design training for social organisers. Methodology should allow us to capture detail on conflict profile (history of violence, social, demographic, cultural make-up etc.), key conflict actors, drivers of conflict and conflict dynamics. 4. Train social organisers: Training provided on gathering data, using detailed methodology. Probably two days in focus areas. Should include research ethics alongside use of specific tools. 5. Field work/data collection: Series of focus group discussions with different interest groups (these need to be identified through steps 1, 2 and 3 above), complemented by Key Informant Interviews with important stakeholders at local and sub-national level (mostly in the field, but potentially in Kabul also). FGDs should be led by the social organisers. 6. Participatory analysis: Bring key field staff together to jointlyanalyse findings from field work. This would take the form of a facilitated workshop. This might focus on first agreeing on key conflict drivers in each location, and then discussing how CDPs intersect with these. It could also include reflections on the process of undertaking the analysis, which could be captured and fed back into the training outline. 7. Report writing: Draft report developed, including recommendations. 8. Validation workshop: Bringing social organisers and potentially representatives from communities to discuss and agree on headline findings and discuss implications. 9. Finalise report Outputs: 1. Local level conflict analysis for four areas, with recommendation on how CDPs intersect with conflict issues in each location. 2. Aggregated recommendations about howCDP development and implementation processes can be adapted to better account for conflict dynamics. 3. Training module and materials for social organizers on conducting conflict analysis. 4. Final report.

participating-org.narrative: Saferworld is a not-for-profit international peacebuilding organisation and has been working to prevent violent conflict and build safer lives for 28 years. Saferworld was founded in 1989 and is a registered charity and company in the UK. In the 1990s we pioneered work for more effective arms controls, and we also began examining the broader elements underlying conflict # such as governance,power, marginalisation, access to resources and development. Our guiding principle # which remains to this day # was that people should be at the heart of all responses to conflict. In 2000 we expanded our policy work and started in-country programming in Kenya and the Western Balkans. We have grown significantly since then: we now work in over 20 countries across East Africa, Europe, CentralAsia, the Middle East, North Africa, South Asia and South East Asia. In all cases, local partners form the backbone to our programme. Our policy and programming covers a range of issues at local, national, regional and international levels including community security, gender, peace and security, justice and development. Today, with headquarters in London and a presence in key regional and policy centres including Brussels, Nairobi, Vienna, Washington DC and Beijing, we remainone of the world#s leading organisations on conflict prevention thinking and practice.
